elements.title: the San Remo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the San Remo (pictured) was once described as an "ATM for Democratic presidential campaigns" in the United States?

elements.title: Robert Williams (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the shop in Cairo designed by Robert Williams for the Davis Bryan Company became a site of "pilgrimage for all Welsh travellers" to Egypt?

elements.title: Fitchburg Cutoff (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Pedro II of Brazil examined the signal system on the Fitchburg Cutoff?

elements.title: Francesco Lanzillotta (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that when Francesco Lanzillotta conducted Dallapiccola's Ulisse at Oper Frankfurt in 2022, a reviewer noted that he "does not shy away from agglomerations of sound"?

elements.title: voted to repeal a law (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 2009, residents of Maine voted to repeal a law that would have legalized same-sex marriage?

elements.title: Eileen Ramsay (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that yachting photographer Eileen Ramsay damaged many Rolleiflex cameras by attempting to take photos at water level?

elements.title: illegal operation (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that "illegal operation" was a common euphemism for abortion in early-20th-century North American newspapers?

elements.title: Bailundo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Ekuikui V was deposed as the king of Bailundo in 2021 and sentenced to six years in prison?
